Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk selinux-policy
exit 0

exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: selinux-policy bug fix update
Vulnerability.Description: The selinux-policy packages contain the rules that govern how confined processes run on the system. This update fixes the following bugs: Previously, the supervdsmServer service was not a part of the SELinux policy for virtualization. Consequently, supervdsmServer was running as SELinux unconfined domain for services and the firewalld daemon was not able to communicate with the superVDSM subprocess. With this update, the SELinux policy for virtualization has been updated to have supervdsmServer running as the virtd_t SELinux domain, which allows firewalld to communicate with superVDSM. (BZ#1172146) Due to missing SELinux policy rules, the sanlock service was not able to send the SIGTERM or SIGKILL signals to the vdsm daemon. With these updated SELinux packages, the rules have been added to allow sanlock with sanlock_t SELinux domain to send SIGTERM or SIGKILL to vdsm with the virtd_t SELinux domain, thus fixing this bug. (BZ#1172147) Users of selinux-policy are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
